bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Ford Foundation is a nonprofit grant-making organization with an extensive history of international leadership in economic development, human rights and microfinance, as well as major U.S. causes, including the environment, civil rights, legal aid, and women's rights, and such domestic challenges as urban development and reproductive health.

The film shows several tiers of options for nonviolent criminals, and discusses the challenges and accomplishments of the programs. scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Based on the autobiography "Born to Rebel" of Morehouse College president Benjamin E. Mays, the documentary examines the life and work of Mays who speaks about his journey from a poor boyhood in South Carolina to becoming President emeritus of Morehouse College. Other speakers include: Dr Martin Luther King Sr., Jimmy Carter (then Governor of Georgia), Coretta Scott King, Samuel DuBois Cook (Duke University), Edward B. Williams (Morehouse College) and John Danforth (Atorney General of Mississippi). Narrated by Harry Belafonte. Written and produced by Chuck Bowen. Directed by Christian Garrison. Produced with a grant from the Ford Foundation. Grant # 75-31. Part of the "Great Georgians" series. Copyright University of Georgia, 1974.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Oshogbo, Western Nigeria. Film discussing the evolution of dance, theater, sculpture, and other traditional fine art practices of the Oshogbo people of Western Nigeria. Made by Francis Speed and Ulli Beier from the University of Ibadan, Nigeria.

The film is a brief description of life in a busy commercial centre that still depends upon and retains its ancient traditions. These are based on the history of the town which was founded on the banks of the river Oshun. This river itself is one of the most important river deities of the Yoruba whose cults spread even as far as Brazil. Aduni Susanne Wenger, a chief priestess of the Obatala cult, is shown rebuilding the once neglected Oshun shrine, with her fellow artists, Adebisi Akanji, OyeWale and Lani. The Beiers show how art based on traditional pagan religion forms the foundation of the modern movement. How painters and sculptors have responded to exposure to modern techniques intelligently and sensitively introduced by Georgina Beier. Oshogbo's vibrant artistic life owes much to the founding of the Mbari Mbayo club by Duro Ladipo, also enthusiastically supported by Twins Seven Seven and Ogunmola. Many of Nigeria's world-renowned artists, play-writes and musicians have passed through Mbari Mbayo's doors. The club also distinguished its self by organizing the exhibition of art from other African regions - something that Ulli Beier was particularly keen to promote. This film presents a unique view of the vibrant, creative life typical of many Yoruba centres during this period. "Yoruba tradition is a living Force." Film by Francis Speed and Ulli Beier. University of Ibadan, Nigeria.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An ethnopsychiatric film of the management of psychiatric disorders by the Yoruba of Western Nigeria for the Human Ecology Fund. Directed by Raymond Prince, MD. Section of Transcultural Psychiatric Studies, McGill University.

The film documents psychiatric disorders and Yerubic medicine in Yeruba, Nigeria. The documentary includes footage of diagnosis, treatment, care of patients, spiritual healing ceremonies, male and female cult practices, and comparisons of traditional Yerubic religion, Islam and Christianity?s relationship to psychiatric illness.

Among the Yoruba, psychiatric disorder is widespread and a set of institutions has been developed to deal with it. There are two basic types of such institutions: firstly, treatment centres managed by herbalists and diviners with specialist knowledge of traditional psychiatric therapy, and secondly, cult groups such as the Gelede masquerade cult for men and the Egun possession cult for women, which provide a setting for the expression of what is otherwise socially unacceptable behaviour. The film shows a number of aspects of both types of institution.
Contains footage of animal sacrifice and female nudity.

scopecontent.p: Produced by Georgia Department of Corrections. The Alternative to Incarceration program of the Georgia Department of Corrections (GDC) is a systematic approach to planned offender management. It provides effective, productive alternatives to prison by means of a continuum of sentencing options incrementally arrayed with increasing degrees of punishment, control, supervision, and offender services.

GDC's alternative sentencing program has become a model for others throughout the nation. The Georgia program has set the standard, clearly demonstrating that innovative sentencing can be an effective part of the criminal justice system. These options protect the public, punish the criminal, provide restitution to the victim and the community, and offer enormous savings to the tax payer.

Funding for this film was provided by a grant from the Ford Foundation in recognition of the selection of the Georgia Department of Corrections as a winner of the Innovations in State and Local Government Award, a program of the Ford Foundation in collaboration with the John F. scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Ford Foundation and the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University established a program to award exemplary initiatives in state and local governments. In 1986, there were more than 1,300 applications with ten winners. The awards committee was headed by former Gov. William G. Milliken of Michigan.

The video profiles the ten award winners. The recipients include: The State of North Carolina, for an engineering program that developed tools and services to help people with disabilities in the workforce. The State of Arizona, for a comprehensive law to conserve underground water used for commercial, household and industrial uses. The City of Rochester, for finding a way to fairly assess property taxes. The Illinois Department of Family Services, for its "One-Church One-Child" program, in which black families adopt black children through their churches. The Illinois Department of Public Aid, for devising a way to improve nursing homes through incentives for employees. Los Angeles County, California, for developing an efficient system of distributing free food daily to more than a million needy citizens. Ingram County, Michigan, for providing child care, counseling, transportation and social services to teenage parents in a rural area through community-wide cooperation. The City of St. Paul for serving elderly people at home rather than removing them to nursing homes, and at less cost. The State of Minnesota for a systematic approach to finding new ways to make new innovations in the full range of state services.

The Social Studies Field Agent Training Program was funded by the Ford Foundation and the US Office of Education in 1970 to train 11 teachers in new ways to teach social studies. The program was based within the College of Arts and Sciences and The School of Education at Indiana University in Bloomington, Indiana. An overarching goal of the program was to improve the speed at which new developments in social studies are taught in the selected elementary and secondary schools. Indiana schools within 300-miles of Bloomington were the primary focus.

Howard D. Mehlinger, a professor within the IU School of Education oversaw the initial feasibility study. He interviewed over 40 teachers, professors, and administrators who saw a need for social studies field agents to serve as go-betweens for professors at universities and teachers in primary and secondary schools. With funding secured in 1970, Dr. Mehlinger oversaw the project. Ultimately, 11 teachers (7 from Indiana and one each from Kentucky, Ohio, Michigan, and West Virginia) were selected for the program. The project followed a Research, Development, Diffusion, and Adoption model. The teachers took a one-year leave of absence from their schools to complete internships with Indiana University faculty from various program areas. They learned about new teaching approaches as well as developments in the social sciences and humanities. They were provided with new innovative teaching kits that included recordings, artifacts, teacher guides, games, slides, and class handouts to bring back to their schools. The Foundation also supported two graduate students to assist with the project and funded workshops and conferences.

The teachers returned to the classroom in the fall with new curricula and teaching materials. They were expected to share their new methods with teachers at their own schools as well as with teachers at nearby schools.
